section: 8. MINIMUM NUMBER OF TOURNAMENTS AND POTENTIAL REPAYMENT OF BASE COMPENSATION A. In each and every calendar year of this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall achieve a satisfactory record of play in a minimum of [* ****] professional golf association events on the SPGA and/or PGA tour (which shall include both the PGA and SPGA Tour Skins Games). If for any reason, CONSULTANT should achieve a satisfactory record of play in less than [*****] SPGA and/or PGA tour events in a calendar year, he shall repay ADAMS GOLF an amount per event for each event under [*****] achieved in the given calendar year as follows: The agreed upon repayment amount per event per calendar year: 1. Year 1. $[*****] 2. Year 2 $[*****] 3. Year 3 $[*****] 4. Year 4 $[*****] 5. Year 5 $[*****] B.Payment shall be made to ADAMS GOLF within three months following the end of the calendar year. For example, if in the calendar year 2005 CONSULTANT achieves a satisfactory record of play in [*****] events, he shall repay ADAMS GOLF [*****] dollars no later than March 31, 2006. C.In the event that CONSULTANT is prevented from competing for reasons outside his control, the parties agree to a good faith attempt to resolve the issues. If a resolution can not be reached, ADAMS GOLF may, at its sole discretion, demand prorated repayment pursuant to the repayment schedule in paragraph 8A above.
explanation: The phrase 'satisfactory record of play' is not defined in the contract. This ambiguity creates uncertainty as to what constitutes a satisfactory record of play. The absence of a clear definition gives ADAMS GOLF significant discretion in determining whether the consultant has met the minimum requirements, potentially leading to disputes.

section: 8. MINIMUM NUMBER OF TOURNAMENTS AND POTENTIAL REPAYMENT OF BASE COMPENSATION A. In each and every calendar year of this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall achieve a satisfactory record of play in a minimum of [* ****] professional golf association events on the SPGA and/or PGA tour (which shall include both the PGA and SPGA Tour Skins Games). If for any reason, CONSULTANT should achieve a satisfactory record of play in less than [*****] SPGA and/or PGA tour events in a calendar year, he shall repay ADAMS GOLF an amount per event for each event under [*****] achieved in the given calendar year as follows: The agreed upon repayment amount per event per calendar year: 1. Year 1. $[*****] 2. Year 2 $[*****] 3. Year 3 $[*****] 4. Year 4 $[*****] 5. Year 5 $[*****] B.Payment shall be made to ADAMS GOLF within three months following the end of the calendar year. For example, if in the calendar year 2005 CONSULTANT achieves a satisfactory record of play in [*****] events, he shall repay ADAMS GOLF [*****] dollars no later than March 31, 2006. C.In the event that CONSULTANT is prevented from competing for reasons outside his control, the parties agree to a good faith attempt to resolve the issues. explanation: The repayment schedule and the number of events requiring repayment are redacted. This missing information makes it impossible to determine the exact financial implications of failing to meet the minimum tournament requirements, creating uncertainty and potentially leading to disputes. While the proration is defined, the variables are not, thus making proration calculation impossible.

section: 18. BASE COMPENSATION For the entire term of this Agreement, from September 1, 2004 through [*****] ADAMS GOLF shall pay CONSULTANT a base compensation of [*****] dollars. The base compensation shall be paid upon completion of each calendar year of the contract.
explanation: The contract term end date is redacted, which creates uncertainty as to the duration of the agreement. Without knowing the agreement's end date, it is impossible to accurately calculate the total base compensation due over the entire term, creating ambiguity and potential disputes about the total financial commitment.

section: 18. BASE COMPENSATION For the entire term of this Agreement, from September 1, 2004 through [*****] ADAMS GOLF shall pay CONSULTANT a base compensation of [*****] dollars. The base compensation shall be paid upon completion of each calendar year of the contract.
explanation: The base compensation amount is redacted. This omission makes it impossible to determine the financial obligations of ADAMS GOLF, creating uncertainty and potentially leading to disputes.

section: 23. TERMINATION FOR CAUSE Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, if either party commits any material breach of this Agreement, the other party may terminate for cause upon giving fifteen (15) days written notice of such cause and provided the breach is not rectified within such thirty (30) day period. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: The paragraph states '...fifteen (15) days written notice of such cause and provided the breach is not rectified within such thirty (30) day period.' This is a contradiction because it states 15 days and 30 days, and the terminology is ambiguous and confusing.

section: 23. TERMINATION FOR CAUSE Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, if either party commits any material breach of this Agreement, the other party may terminate for cause upon giving fifteen (15) days written notice of such cause and provided the breach is not rectified within such thirty (30) day period. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: The clause states that upon termination for cause, the consultant must repay ADAMS GOLF for the unperformed portion of the agreement, calculated as described in paragraph 8A. However, if ADAMS GOLF is terminating the agreement due to the consultant's breach, requiring repayment seems punitive. It might be more appropriate to only seek damages directly related to the breach, rather than a full repayment based on a potentially unrelated performance clause. This creates an internal contradiction as the remedy seems disproportionate to the potential harm.
